issues.text: The common question arising for decision in these four appeals is whether the income derived by the respondent, Indian Sugar Mills Association, from its sugar export division is exempt from tax under sec. 4 3 i of the Income Tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: The companymon question arising for decision in these four appeals is whether the income derived by the respondent, Indian Sugar Mills Association, from its sugar export division is exempt from tax under sec. 4  3   i  of the Income Tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case and on proper construction of the Rules and Regulations of the Association, the Tribunal was justified in holding that the income of the Association derived from the business of export of sugar and interest from current and fixed deposits were not exempt from tax under section 4 3 i of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

The claim for exemption appears to have been based on the objects mentioned in Rules 3 a and 3 b and on the first part of clause a of Rule 4.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Association the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court at Calcutta under sec. 66 1 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case and on proper construction of the Rules and Regulations of the Association, the Tribunal was justified in holding that the in- come of the Association derived from the business of export of sugar and interest from current and fixed deposits were not exempt from tax under section 4 3 i of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

arguments.court_reasoning: Discharges High Court answer and answers in affirmative for Revenue

arguments.claim: Clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 3 set out primary objects of general public utility; other objects ancillary; Rule 4(a) imposes legal obligation to hold income for charitable purposes

anchor.surface_text: In case before us the High Court held that clauses a and b of Rule 3 of the Rules of the Association, quoted above, set out the primary objects of the Association which were objects of general public utility, and the other objects appearing from the remaining clauses of Rule 3 were only ancillary. Relying further on a part of Rule 4 a , which we have reproduced above, providing that no part of the income and property of the Association was to be paid or transferred by way of dividend or bonus or otherwise by way of profit to the members of the Association, the High Court came to the conclusion that the Association was under a legal obligation to hold the income it derived from the business of export of sugar for charitable purposes.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nd the other purposes, number by themselves religious or charitable, are ancillary and serves to achieve the main purpose. Assuming clauses  a  and  b

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule 64 allows profit distribution; cannot select only some rules as primary; trade union objects include non-charitable primaries

arguments.claim: Question to be decided on principles from Trustees of the Tribune (customary law and common opinion standard), All India Spinners Association, and Andhra Chamber of Commerce

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed that the question referred to it should be decided upon the principles laid down by the Privy Council in re The Trustees of the Tribune, 7 I.T.R. 415 and All India Spinners Association v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay, 12 I.T.R. 482 and by the Supreme Court in Commissioner of Income-Tax, Madras v. Andhra Chamber of Commerce, 55 I.T.R. 722. Of the several principles stated in the Tribune case supra , the one to which the High Court made special reference is that in countries to which English ideas may be inapplicable, the courts must in general apply the standard of customary law and common opinion amongst the community to which the parties interested belong in deciding whether an object is of general public utility.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ss of export of sugar and interest from current and fixed deposits were number exempt from tax under section 4 3   i  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 19

arguments.court_reasoning: Customary principle irrelevant as no conflict between English and Indian conceptions; Spinners observation on private gain relevant; distinguishes Andhra

arguments.claim: Power conferred on Committee by Rule 64 to decide how profits applied is only incidental to carrying out primary charitable objects

anchor.surface_text: We are not prepared to accept the submission made on behalf of the respondent that the power conferred on the Committee by Rule 64 to decide how the profits are to be applied is only incidental to the carrying out of the primary objects. which are charitable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Resolution at a General Meeting of the. Association held for the purpose. Rule 64 thus permits dist

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in Rule 64 suggests it; no indication profits must be partly set apart for charitable purposes

arguments.claim: If Rule 64 inconsistent with primary objects, treat as void and of no consequence; repugnancy rule applies (first words in deed prevail)

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Pal for the respondent also submitted that if Rule 64 appeared to be inconsistent with-the primary objects, it should be treated as void and of no consequence. Undoubtedly Rule 4 a and Rule 64 are repugnant to each other. But the rule of construction of deeds and wills on which Dr. Pal relied, that in case of repugnancy the first words in a deed and the last words in a will shall prevail, is not applicable to the rules and regulations of a registered trade union in order to find out its real object.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Association v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay  supra  it cannot be said that the Association in

arguments.court_reasoning: Repugnancy rule not applicable to rules of registered trade union

arguments.claim: Rule 64 makes Rule 4(a) prohibition nugatory, permits distribution of profits introducing private gain inconsistent with general public utility; follows All India Spinners

anchor.surface_text: Assuming clauses a and b of Rule 3 disclosed objects of general public utility, it is necessary to examine some of the other Rules of the Association to find out if it held the income derived from the business wholly for charitable purposes. The general prohibition contained in the first part of Rule 4 a against sharing of profits by the members appears to have been made almost nugatory by Rule 64 which is as follows Subject to such rules as the General Meeting may frame or prescribe for declaration of dividend and distribution of profits, the profits of the Association shall be applied in such manner as the Committee may in their discretion think fit provided nevertheless that no distribution of profits amongst members will be made unless sanctioned by a Resolution at a General Meeting of the. Association held for the purpose. Rule 64 thus permits distribution of profits among the members on a resolution being passed for the purpose at a General Meeting of the Association. Under Rule 64 the Committee of the Association may in their discretion decide to apportion the entire profits among the members of the Association leaving nothing to be applied towards the alleged primary objects.

arguments.claim: Present case distinguished from Andhra Chamber of Commerce as here Rule 64 introduces profit motive, unlike there

anchor.surface_text: Rule 64 introduces an element of private gain which is inconsistent with the object of general public utility and following the decision in A11 India Spinners Association v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay supra it cannot be said that the Association in the instant case held the income it derived from its business of export of sugar wholly for charitable purposes. This is also what distinguishes the present case from the Andhra Chamber of Commerce case where it was found that the Chamber of Commerce had no profit motive, that its objects were to promote and protect the trade, commerce and industries and to stimulate their development and its other objects were ancillary and incidental to the principal objects.

arguments.claim: Cannot rewrite rules of registered trade union by declaring some void or of no effect; all rules coexist

anchor.surface_text: We have no right to assume some of the stated objects of the Association as primary to declare others in apparent conflict with them as of no effect. Rules 3, 4 and 64, all framed by the Association as a Trade Union, coexist. We have no right to rewrite the rules of a registered trade union by deleting any of them.

arguments.claim: Only clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 3 are not the primary objects; other rules not merely ancillary; as trade union per s.2(h), objects like regulating employment, employer-employee relations, member controversies, restrictive conditions are primary trade union purposes, not charitable

anchor.surface_text: We also find it difficult to accept that only clauses a and b of Rule 3 represent the primary objects of the Association and the other Rules are all ancillary and incidental. The Association is a Trade Union. Section 2 h of the Trade Unions Act, 1926 defines Trade Union as meaning any combination, whether temporary or permanent, formed primarily for the purpose of regulating the relation between workmen and employers or between workmen and workmen, or between employers and employers, or for imposing restrictive conditions on the conduct of any trade or business, and includes any federation of two or more Trade Unions There is a proviso to this definition which is not relevant on the question under consideration. The definition itself sets out the primary purposes for which a trade union can be formed. The objects of the Association listed under Rule 3 include the following To regulate terms and conditions of employment in the Mills and Factories. To promote good relations between the employers and the employees. To adjust controversies between members of this Association. To establish just and equitable principles in trade and impose restrictive conditions on the conduct of sugar trade and business. These are all primary purposes of a Trade Union. Rule 3 b also may possibly be. taken as a trade union object. Assuming Rule 3 a could be the primary object of a trade union, the other objects named in clauses c , d , l and n of Rule 3 also fall in the same category, and it is not possible to speak of one of them as ancillary or incidental to another. These other objects cannot also be called charitable purposes within the meaning of section 4 3 i , even assuming that in some remote and indirect manner they might be of some public utility.

arguments.claim: Tribune customary law principle irrelevant as no conflict between English and Indian conceptions of charitable purpose

anchor.surface_text: Referring to this principle the High Court observed that section 4 3 i is of wider amplitude than what is known as religious or charitable purposes in English Law and a purpose of general public utility has to be ascertained with reference to conceptions prevailing in our country. We are afraid we do not see how this principle has relevance on the question under consideration in the present case because no conflict arises here between the English and the Indian conceptions of charitable purpose.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was justified in holding that the income of the Association derived from the business of export of sugar and interest from current and fixed deposits were not exempt from tax under section 4(3)(i) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above we allow these appeals, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it, and answer the question in the affirmative and in favour

holdings.reasoning_summary: Association's rules permit profit distribution to members under Rule 64 and include non-charitable primary trade union objects, preventing income from being held wholly for charitable purposes.

holdings.text: The Association did not hold the income derived from the business wholly for charitable purposes within section 4(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: Rule 64 introduces an element of private gain which is inconsistent with the object of general public utility and following the decision in A11 India Spinners Association v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay supra it cannot be said that the Association

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 64 permits distribution of profits to members, introducing private gain inconsistent with general public utility per All India Spinners Association.

holdings.text: The present case is distinguished from Andhra Chamber of Commerce because Rule 64 introduces profit motive unlike there.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 64 introduces an element of private gain which is inconsistent with the object of general public utility and following the decision in A11 India Spinners Association v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay supra it cannot be said that the Association in the instant case held the income it derived from its business of export of sugar wholly for charitable purposes. This is also what distinguishes the present case from the Andhra Chamber of Commerce case where it was found that the Chamber of Commerce had no profit motive

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike Andhra Chamber, here Rule 64 allows profit distribution, evidencing profit motive.

holdings.text: Rule of construction of deeds and wills that in case of repugnancy the first words in a deed and the last words in a will shall prevail is not applicable to rules of a registered trade union.

anchor.surface_text: But the rule of construction of deeds and wills on which Dr. Pal relied, that in case of repugnancy the first words in a deed and the last words in a will shall prevail, is not applicable to the rules and regulations of a registered trade union in order to find out its real object.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules of registered trade union must be construed as a whole; no rewriting by applying deed/will rules.

holdings.text: Courts have no right to rewrite rules of a registered trade union by declaring some objects primary and others of no effect.

anchor.surface_text: We have no right to assume some of the stated objects of the Association as primary to declare others in apparent conflict with them as of no effect. Rules 3, 4 and 64, all framed by the Association as a Trade Union, coexist. We have no right to rewrite the rules of a registered trade union by deleting any of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All rules coexist; cannot selectively void rules to favor charitable claim.

holdings.text: Only clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 3 do not represent the primary objects of the Association; other trade union objects are also primary and not ancillary.

anchor.surface_text: We also find it difficult to accept that only clauses a and b of Rule 3 represent the primary objects of the Association and the other Rules are all ancillary and incidental.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per s.2(h) Trade Unions Act, regulating employment, employer relations, controversies, restrictive conditions are primary trade union purposes, not ancillary to promotion objects.

holdings.text: Objects like regulating employment terms, promoting employer-employee relations, adjusting member controversies, imposing trade restrictions are primary trade union purposes and not charitable under section 4(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The objects of the Association listed under Rule 3 include the following To regulate terms and conditions of employment in the Mills and Factories. To promote good relations between the employers and the employees. To adjust controversies between members of this Association. To establish just and equitable principles in trade and impose restrictive conditions on the conduct of sugar trade and business. These are all primary purposes of a Trade Union.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Match statutory definition of trade union primary purposes; not charitable even if indirect public utility.

holdings.text: The principle from Trustees of the Tribune on customary law and common opinion has no relevance here.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to this principle the High Court observed that section 4 3 i is of wider amplitude than what is known as religious or charitable purposes in English Law and a purpose of general public utility has to be ascertained with reference to conceptions prevailing in our country. We are afraid we do not see how this principle has relevance on the question under consideration in the present case because no conflict arises here between the English and the Indian conceptions of charitable purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No conflict between English and Indian conceptions of charitable purpose in this case.

anchor.surface_text: The objects of the Association listed under Rule 3 include the following To regulate terms and conditions of employment in the Mills and Factories. To promote good relations between the employers and the employees. To adjust controversies between members of this Association. To establish just and equitable principles in trade and impose restrictive conditions on the conduct of sugar trade and business. These are all primary purposes of a Trade Union.

For the reasons stated above we allow these appeals, discharge the answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it, and answer the question in the affirmative and in favour of the Revenue.
